awd_titl_txt: Cohomological periods and high rank lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
As was realized by Descartes, the solution of algebraic equations can be realized geometrically. This observation was the start of a rich interaction between algebra and geometry. This project will study two topics in number theory. The first concerns the shape of arithmetic manifolds -- i.e., certain geometries defined by their number theoretic symmetries. The PI has conjectured the existence of new structures that govern their shape (mathematically speaking their topology), which he will investigate in more detail. The second topic relates to lattices of high dimension. These are a topic of interest in modern cryptography; on the other hand, a satisfactory mathematical theory of them is not yet available, and this project aims to develop such a theory.
 
More specifically, the PI has formulated a conjecture that specifies the values of "periods" of arithmetic locally symmetric spaces -- i.e., the numbers obtained by pairing homology classes with normalized differential forms. This conjecture is interesting because it suggests a relationship between these homology groups, and certain motivic cohomology groups. The PI will study this conjecture and attempt to give evidence for it. Concerning lattices, the PI will study in particular the following questions: What is the diameter of the space of n-dimensional lattices, how do the short vectors in a typical n-dimensional lattice behave, and why does the LLL lattice reduction algorithm behave so well? A basic tool will be the analysis of automorphic forms on GL(n) for large n, and the PI will also study related questions about automorphic forms in the high-dimensional limit.

por.por_cntn:
A major focus of this project was the discovery of hidden symmetries governing the topology of "arithmetic locally symmetric spaces." These latter are highly structured geometric objects which have become one of the central foci of modern number theory because of their role in the Langlands program.   Computations show that they show a certain degeneracy in their topology -- a repeating pattern of invariants across several different dimensions (precisely: cohomological degrees).

I proposed  a mechanism that explained this degeneracy -- hidden symmetries that knit together different dimensions. Over the course of this project,  my collaborators and I provided rather precise conjectures about this mechanism. These conjectures are very far from being proved in general,  but  we were able to provide evidence in some nontrivial cases.  All in all, this work puts these hidden symmetries on a firm footing, suitable for further mathematical investigation.

Much of the evidence for these conjectures are based on the fact that there exist miraculous formulas  for certain integrals of certain special functions on these arithmetic locally symmetric spaces.  Together with David Ben-Zvi and Yiannis Sakellaridis, we introduced a paradigm called "relative Langlands duality" to study such formulas. It is based on the observation that these formulas often come in pairs -- one can be "turned inside out" to obtain a different formula.  Relative Langlands duality is built atop  an existing central structure of the Langlands program (the duality of reductive groups). Moreover, it is parallel to certain dualities that have been studied in quantum field theory.

The integrals of special functions mentioned in the last paragraph sometimes cannot be evaluated, but it is still important to know something about them -- for example, it is very useful to be able to estimate how large they are.  Typically, these integrals are very high dimensional and   standard techniques of doing this become prohibitively complicated;  one of the original questions of the proposal was to develop better techniques for this problem. This has been accomplished in a paper I wrote with Paul Nelson. This paper borrows ideas from the "orbit method" in representation theory to develop a  robust and general way to estimate such integrals. 

 The proposal also supported the training of 4 graduate students.
